title: St. Francis Xavier College Church Plaza
summary: Students explored subsurface remains adjacent to the College Church, uncovering the footprint of earlier walkways and chapel landscaping.
timelineSummary: Mapped masonry retaining walls and landscaping features that framed the expanding College Church plaza during the 1870s.
longDescription: Archaeology students opened a series of test units across the plaza to document the evolution of sacred space at the heart of SLU. Their work revealed stacked stone retaining walls, compacted cinder pathways, and landscaping soils that speak to the campus beautification efforts that followed the church's 1884 dedication.

title: Pius XII Memorial Library Quad
summary: Geophysical survey mapped buried utilities, tree planting pits, and pathways that crisscrossed the library quad prior to its modern redesign.
timelineSummary: Combined GPR and soil cores to reconstruct the 1950s landscaping plan and identify zones for future excavation.
longDescription: SLU archaeologists collaborated with Facilities to model the subsurface architecture beneath the heavily used quad. By tracking reflections from multiple depths, the team located mid-century steam lines, forgotten foundation pads from temporary barracks, and layered planting soils associated with the campus's post-war expansion.

title: DuBourg Hall Steps
summary: Excavations at the original administrative building revealed the remnants of the grand staircase and early campus utilities.
timelineSummary: Documented limestone step treads, a brick drainage culvert, and deposits left by student gatherings at the foot of the hall.
longDescription: A 6 x 4 m block excavation exposed the interface between DuBourg Hall and the surrounding parade ground. Investigators traced the sequence of stair construction, repairs, and adaptive reuse, while microartifact sampling captured evidence of student traditions including class bonfires and commencement ceremonies.

title: Griesedieck Complex Courtyard
summary: Systematic shovel tests documented landscape fills and communal spaces associated with 1960s residential towers.
timelineSummary: Identified borrow soils, planting beds, and recreational surfaces that supported a generation of residential students.
longDescription: Undergraduate archaeologists excavated shovel test pits across the courtyard to study how the construction of the Griesedieck Complex reshaped campus ecology. The team recorded thick mechanically deposited fills, remnants of brick patios, and environmental samples capturing the courtyard's evolution into a social hub.

title: Bannister House Laboratory
summary: Historic Bannister House hosts the Campus Archaeology lab where student volunteers catalog materials from across SLU excavation projects.
timelineSummary: Transformed a historic residence into a teaching laboratory equipped for washing, cataloging, and analyzing artifact collections.
longDescription: The Bannister House laboratory is the heart of the program's artifact stewardship. Inside the 1890s residence, students clean and catalog finds, digitize field records, and welcome community partners to explore SLU's heritage collections. The lab anchors public archaeology programming with open houses and artifact identification days.
